title: Fix #88
body:
TestedOnSupplier now simply uses "ints" to describe its assignments.

Fixes #88.

title: Fixed #170: display actual object value in assertNull()
body: I've found simple issue to fix. Please merge it or tell me what else I need to implement to make it acceptable to merge.

title: Issue 355: Improve Assume to allow passing custom message (details).
unconclusive error message
body:
if a testclass is annotated with @RunWith(Parameterized.class) and does have a single constructor that is not public. After using eclipse "RunAs->JUnit Test" the following error message is emitted:

java.lang.assertionerror: expected 1 but was 0

which took me (as a beginner) some time to unriddle...

Maybe this message can be more informative. Like eg "Public Constructor not found"

Matthias

title: Put code style settings under version control
body: It would be convenient to enforce code style conventions (like imports) by committing them as Eclipse 'project specific settings' into the VCS. The Eclipse project settings are already under version control anyway. That way, new and unwary developers that wish to contribute to the project automatically use the correct code style.

title: Wrong JavaDoc in MethodRule and some TestRules
body:
The JavaDoc of the ``MethodRule`` interface is wrong: ``ErrorCollector``, ``ExpectedException`` etc. are no ``MethodRule``s anymore. They do implement ``TestRule`` now.

Additionally JavaDoc for ``Timeout`` and ``Verifier`` should be improved removing the reference to ``TestRule``:

``
@Rule
public final Timeout globalTimeout= new Timeout(20);
``
and
``
@Rule
 public final Verifier verifier = new Verifier() { 
.....
``
instead of 
``
@Rule
public TestRule globalTimeout= new Timeout(20);
``
etc.

This version of the example is much better because:
 * it demonstrates best practices
 * works for JUnit 4.10 and above but also for JUnit 4.9 + JUnit 4.8
 * JUnit interfaces might be instable and subject to frequent changes

title: Allow users to define the parent directory used by the TemporaryFolder
body: This is something that some of the users I work with have been requesting. The default behavior is left unchanged, but there is now an option to determine where a temporary folder's parent is.

title: testNameAsc (org.junit.internal.MethodSorterTest) non-deterministic results with OpenJDK7
body:
I've hit this while working on the transition the Ubuntu archive in the current development release to OpenJDK7 as the default Java version.

This requires re-compilation/verification of all packages against OpenJDK7.

Ubuntu actually has JUnit 4.10 - which suffers a different test failure with openjdk-7 (but I think its much the same cause):

     [java] There was 1 failure:
     [java] 1) useChildHarvester(org.junit.tests.running.classes.ParentRunnerTest)
     [java] org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<before [apple after before banana] after afterAll > but was:<before [banana after before apple] after afterAll >

When compiling the latest 4.11-SNAPSHOT from github I sometimes hit the following test failure (about 75% of the time):

     [java] There was 1 failure:
     [java] 1) testNameAsc(org.junit.internal.MethodSorterTest)
     [java] org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<...(), void epsilon(), [int gamma(), void gamma(boolean])]> but was:<...(), void epsilon(), [void gamma(boolean), int gamma(])]>

I noted the comments in the MethodSorter class header and I'm assuming it something todo with deterministic sorting specific openjdk-7 - it fine with openjdk-6.

title: New test and fix for issue 80
body: New test and fix for issue 80, adding support for external RunListener implementations, which get automatically loaded at startup through the Java 6+ SPI (ie, java.util.ServiceLocator). Listener implementations are specified in third-party "META-INF/services/org.junit.runner.notification.RunListener" files made available in the runtime classpath (for example, in the jar file of another testing tool which wants to integrate with JUnit).

title: Restore deterministic test ordering.
body: Pull patch from Kevin Cooney in https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/429#issuecomment-5815166

title: Adding methods to the Junit Test Suite
If TestWatchman#failed() or #finished() throw an exception, the Rule hides the original exception
body:
Note this issue happens for `TestWatcher`, too

The `TestWatchman` and `TestWatcher` both have the problem that if `failed()` or `finished()` throws a RuntimeException, that's the exception that will be given as the cause of the test failure, even if the test method threw an exception. Instead, we should change `TestWatchman` and `TestWatcher` to throw MultipleFailureException if both the test and the rule throws an exception.

title: TestWatcher javadoc was not correct for example method names
body: Redid the example in the javadoc to be in line with new method names

title: Fixes #295 clarify javadoc for Result
body: Fixes #295 using the suggested description in the comments for #295

title: Fixes #427 inconsistent javadoc for test rules
body:
The examples for some test rules used

public TestRule chain= RuleChain...

whereas others did not refer to TestRule, they used the class name.
Changed all of those who refered to TestRule to use the class name.

The other part is fixed by #372.

title: Fixes #51 Verifier is abstract to indicate that it should be extended
body: This partially fixes #51. TestWatchman is deprecated, so has not been modified.

title: Fixes #67 add javadoc since
body:
Using the contents of maven jars, added the javadoc tag since to all of the classes, using the earliest version in which the class appeared. If there was no jar in which it appeared, I assumed 4.11.

If there was no javadoc comment for a class, I added it, but only containing the since.

I did not do the junit.framework classes.

Sorry about the number of files changed :-)

title: closed method assertEquals with }
body: The assertEquals method in assert.java was not closed with a curly brace, which prevented building from source.

title: Make MethodSorters deterministic in JDK 7
body: Two of the MethodSorters implementations where not deterministic in JDK 7 (where Class.getDeclaredMethods() returns methods in an arbitrary order). Also fixed some incorrect Javadoc

title: fix for issue 283 (recursive temp folders) caused incompatibility
body:
The fix for issue 283, described here:

- `TemporaryFolder#newFolder(String... folderNames)` creates
recursively deep temporary folders
[@rodolfoliviero, closing gh-283]

causes existing uses of (the now missing) TemporaryFolder#newFolder(String) to fail with NoSuchMethodError. If this was deliberate, then that's fine -- we'll edit and recompile, but I just wanted to be sure you were aware.

title: Compare full signature of methods with same name.
body:
When sorting methods in ascending order, compare the full signature
if the methods have the same name.

title: Make method sorter more readable
body: Cosmetic refactorings to make MethodSorter more readable (to me, at least ;P).

title: JUnit should have an exhaustive listener framework
body:
JUnit should have a listener model that provides all the events from test execution (run starting, suite starting, test case starting, test starting, failed, error, success, timeout, theories data, assumption failed etc etc), including a reference to the test/suite class and a Method object for the method at hand.

It should also allow for hooking in the listeners in a single place for an entire set of tests in an unobtrusive way, like a properties file (or possibly as an annotation on a suite, or a specific class in the execution tree). 

Rules are sort of listeners, but they require more detailed manipulations of tests. RunListener provides only a fragment of the available information. If the listener framework can also change the test execution (AOP-style), the Rule implementation, as well as the RunListener, could be build on top of this framework.

title: Fixes #67 no since javadoc
body:
Using the contents of maven jars, added the javadoc tag since to all of the classes, using the earliest version in which the class appeared. If there was no jar in which it appeared, I assumed 4.11.

If there was no javadoc comment for a class, I added it, but only containing the since.

I did not do the junit.framework classes, or experimental classes, or internal.

title: Change timeout to be a long
Removed "GENERATOR" meta for "Microsoft FrontPage 4.0" from index.html
body: I understand that this file was generated long back using Frontpage, but I think we don't need this meta tag anymore. What do you think? Does it serve any purpose?

title: DataPoints need to be Public
body: Theories warns if field annotated with @DataPoints is not static, but silently ignores if not public.  Update behaviour so it consistently provides warnings.

title: AllMembersSupplier.addMultiPointMethods() swallows exceptions
Timeout accepts a long value, with an optional TimeUnit
Making it possible to instantiate Descriptions for individual tests without an actual Java class
body:
When using Cucumber-JVM and running BDD tests using its JUnit runner implementation, one doesn't actually have any real Java class within which a test case lives. Instead, a text string that corresponds to a Scenario description is used, and individual test cases correspond to steps within the scenario. Currently, it's not possible to instantiate test case descriptions without also indicating which Java class that test case lives in, which means that Cucumber-JVM has been using the createSuiteDescription method. However, as described in cucumber/cucumber-jvm#322, that leads to problems as the descriptions created cannot be parsed as 'class + method' using the regular expression in Description.

The proposed code changes fix that by adding a new test case description factory method that takes 'any string' instead of a class name. 

Also, it feels like the solution of storing the class name + test case name as a single string and parsing things out of it is perhaps less than ideal, and splitting it into two strings might be better. But changing that seems like it might have side effects I don't understand, so I've left it as is.
